segment.source: Update Windows 10 images with provisioning packages (Windows 10)
segment.target: Update Windows 10 images with provisioning packages (Windows 10)

segment.source: Use a provisioning package to apply settings, profiles, and file assets to a Windows 10 image.
segment.target: Use a provisioning package to apply settings, profiles, and file assets to a Windows 10 image.

segment.source: Update Windows 10 images with provisioning packages
segment.target: Update Windows 10 images with provisioning packages

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows 10 Mobile
segment.target: Windows 10 Mobile

segment.source: Use a provisioning package to apply settings, profiles, and file assets to a Windows 10 image.
segment.target: Use a provisioning package to apply settings, profiles, and file assets to a Windows 10 image.

segment.source: In Windows 10, you can apply a provisioning package at any time.
segment.target: In Windows 10, you can apply a provisioning package at any time.

segment.source: A provisioning package can include management instructions and policies, installation of specific apps, customization of network connections and policies, and more.
segment.target: A provisioning package can include management instructions and policies, installation of specific apps, customization of network connections and policies, and more.

segment.source: You can include provisioning packages when you build a Windows image.
segment.target: You can include provisioning packages when you build a Windows image.

segment.source: This way, you can create a single provisioning package that you can add to different hardware-specific images.
segment.target: This way, you can create a single provisioning package that you can add to different hardware-specific images.

segment.source: You can also put a provisioning package on a USB drive or SD card to apply to off-the-shelf devices.
segment.target: You can also put a provisioning package on a USB drive or SD card to apply to off-the-shelf devices.

segment.source: You can even send the provisioning package to someone in email.
segment.target: You can even send the provisioning package to someone in email.

segment.source: Rather than wiping a device and applying a new system image when you need to change configuration, you can reset the device to its original state and then apply a new provisioning package.
segment.target: Rather than wiping a device and applying a new system image when you need to change configuration, you can reset the device to its original state and then apply a new provisioning package.

segment.source: For details about the settings you can customize in provisioning packages, see Windows Provisioning settings reference.
segment.target: For details about the settings you can customize in provisioning packages, see Windows Provisioning settings reference.

segment.source: Advantages
segment.target: Advantages

segment.source: You can configure new devices without reimaging.
segment.target: You can configure new devices without reimaging.

segment.source: Works on both mobile and desktop devices.
segment.target: Works on both mobile and desktop devices.

segment.source: No network connectivity required.
segment.target: No network connectivity required.

segment.source: Simple for people to apply.
segment.target: Simple for people to apply.

segment.source: Ensure compliance and security before a device is enrolled in MDM.
segment.target: Ensure compliance and security before a device is enrolled in MDM.

segment.source: Create package
segment.target: Create package

segment.source: Use the Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD) tool included in the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (ADK) for Windows 10 to create a runtime provisioning package.
segment.target: Use the Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD) tool included in the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (ADK) for Windows 10 to create a runtime provisioning package.

segment.source: Install the ADK.
segment.target: Install the ADK.

originalData.data: `%windir%\Program Files (x86)\Windows Kits\10\Assessment and Deployment Kit\Imaging and Configuration Designer\x86\ICD.exe`

segment.source: Open Windows ICD (by default, ).
segment.target: Open Windows ICD (by default, ).

segment.source: Choose New provisioning package.
segment.target: Choose New provisioning package.

segment.source: Name your project, and click Next.
segment.target: Name your project, and click Next.

segment.source: Choose Common to all Windows editions and click Next.
segment.target: Choose Common to all Windows editions and click Next.

segment.source: On New project, click Finish.
segment.target: On New project, click Finish.

segment.source: The workspace for your package opens.
segment.target: The workspace for your package opens.

segment.source: Configure settings.
segment.target: Configure settings.

segment.source: Learn more about specific settings in provisioning packages.
segment.target: Learn more about specific settings in provisioning packages.

segment.source: On the File menu, select Save.
segment.target: On the File menu, select Save.

segment.source: On the Export menu, select Provisioning package.
segment.target: On the Export menu, select Provisioning package.

segment.source: Change Owner to IT Admin, which will set the precedence of this provisioning package higher than provisioning packages applied to this device from other sources, and then select Next.
segment.target: Change Owner to IT Admin, which will set the precedence of this provisioning package higher than provisioning packages applied to this device from other sources, and then select Next.

segment.source: Set a value for Package Version.
segment.target: Set a value for Package Version.

segment.source: Tip
segment.target: Tip

segment.source: You can make changes to existing packages and change the version number to update previously applied packages.
segment.target: You can make changes to existing packages and change the version number to update previously applied packages.

segment.source: Optional.
segment.target: Optional.

segment.source: In the Provisioning package security window, you can choose to encrypt the package and enable package signing.
segment.target: In the Provisioning package security window, you can choose to encrypt the package and enable package signing.

segment.source: Enable package encryption - If you select this option, an auto-generated password will be shown on the screen.
segment.target: Enable package encryption - If you select this option, an auto-generated password will be shown on the screen.

segment.source: Enable package signing - If you select this option, you must select a valid certificate to use for signing the package.
segment.target: Enable package signing - If you select this option, you must select a valid certificate to use for signing the package.

segment.source: You can specify the certificate by clicking Select... and choosing the certificate you want to use to sign the package.
segment.target: You can specify the certificate by clicking Select... and choosing the certificate you want to use to sign the package.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: We recommend that you include a trusted provisioning certificate in your provisioning package.
segment.target: We recommend that you include a trusted provisioning certificate in your provisioning package.

segment.source: When the package is applied to a device, the certificate is added to the system store and any package signed with that certificate thereafter can be applied silently.
segment.target: When the package is applied to a device, the certificate is added to the system store and any package signed with that certificate thereafter can be applied silently.

segment.source: Click Next to specify the output location where you want the provisioning package to go once it's built.
segment.target: Click Next to specify the output location where you want the provisioning package to go once it's built.

segment.source: By default, Windows ICD uses the project folder as the output location.
segment.target: By default, Windows ICD uses the project folder as the output location.

segment.source: Optionally, you can click Browse to change the default output location.
segment.target: Optionally, you can click Browse to change the default output location.

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: Click Build to start building the package.
segment.target: Click Build to start building the package.

segment.source: The project information is displayed in the build page and the progress bar indicates the build status.
segment.target: The project information is displayed in the build page and the progress bar indicates the build status.

segment.source: If you need to cancel the build, click Cancel.
segment.target: If you need to cancel the build, click Cancel.

segment.source: This cancels the current build process, closes the wizard, and takes you back to the Customizations Page.
segment.target: This cancels the current build process, closes the wizard, and takes you back to the Customizations Page.

segment.source: If your build fails, an error message will show up that includes a link to the project folder.
segment.target: If your build fails, an error message will show up that includes a link to the project folder.

segment.source: You can scan the logs to determine what caused the error.
segment.target: You can scan the logs to determine what caused the error.

segment.source: Once you fix the issue, try building the package again.
segment.target: Once you fix the issue, try building the package again.

segment.source: If your build is successful, the name of the provisioning package, output directory, and project directory will be shown.
segment.target: If your build is successful, the name of the provisioning package, output directory, and project directory will be shown.

segment.source: If you choose, you can build the provisioning package again and pick a different path for the output package.
segment.target: If you choose, you can build the provisioning package again and pick a different path for the output package.

segment.source: To do this, click Back to change the output package name and path, and then click Next to start another build.
segment.target: To do this, click Back to change the output package name and path, and then click Next to start another build.

segment.source: If you are done, click Finish to close the wizard and go back to the Customizations Page.
segment.target: If you are done, click Finish to close the wizard and go back to the Customizations Page.

segment.source: Select the output location link to go to the location of the package.
segment.target: Select the output location link to go to the location of the package.

segment.source: You can provide that .ppkg to others through any of the following methods:
segment.target: You can provide that .ppkg to others through any of the following methods:

segment.source: Shared network folder
segment.target: Shared network folder

segment.source: SharePoint site
segment.target: SharePoint site

segment.source: Removable media (USB/SD)
segment.target: Removable media (USB/SD)

segment.source: Email
segment.target: Email

segment.source: USB tether (mobile only)
segment.target: USB tether (mobile only)

segment.source: NFC (mobile only)
segment.target: NFC (mobile only)

segment.source: Add package to image
segment.target: Add package to image

segment.source: To add a provisioning package to Windows 10 for desktop editions (Home, Pro, Enterprise, and Education)
segment.target: To add a provisioning package to Windows 10 for desktop editions (Home, Pro, Enterprise, and Education)

segment.source: Follow the steps in the "To build an image for Windows 10 for desktop editions" section in Use the Windows ICD command-line interface.
segment.target: Follow the steps in the "To build an image for Windows 10 for desktop editions" section in Use the Windows ICD command-line interface.

segment.source: To add a provisioning package to a Windows 10 Mobile image
segment.target: To add a provisioning package to a Windows 10 Mobile image

segment.source: Follow the steps in the "To build an image for Windows 10 Mobile or Windows 10 IoT Core (IoT Core)" section in Use the Windows ICD command-line interface.
segment.target: Follow the steps in the "To build an image for Windows 10 Mobile or Windows 10 IoT Core (IoT Core)" section in Use the Windows ICD command-line interface.

segment.source: The provisioning package is placed in the FFU image and is flashed or sector written to the device.
segment.target: The provisioning package is placed in the FFU image and is flashed or sector written to the device.

segment.source: During device setup time, the provisioning engine starts and consumes the packages.
segment.target: During device setup time, the provisioning engine starts and consumes the packages.

segment.source: Learn more
segment.target: Learn more

segment.target: Build and apply a provisioning package

segment.target: Provisioning Windows 10 Devices with New Tools
